AmplitudeEnvelope.description:
Tone.AmplitudeEnvelope is a Tone.Envelope connected to a gain node. 
         Unlike Tone.Envelope, which outputs the envelope's value, Tone.AmplitudeEnvelope accepts
         an audio signal as the input and will apply the envelope to the amplitude
         of the signal. Read more about ADSR Envelopes on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthesizer#ADSR_envelope).

params.description:
The amount of time it takes for the envelope to go from 
                              0 to it's maximum value.
params.name: attack

params.description:
The period of time after the attack that it takes for the envelope
                      	to fall to the sustain value.
params.name: decay

params.description:
The percent of the maximum value that the envelope rests at until
                               	the release is triggered.
params.name: sustain

params.description: The amount of time after the release is triggered it takes to reach 0.
params.name: release

Analyser.description:
Wrapper around the native Web Audio's 
         [AnalyserNode](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#idl-def-AnalyserNode).
         Extracts FFT or Waveform data from the incoming signal.

params.description:
The size of the FFT. Value must be a power of 
                      two in the range 32 to 32768.
params.name: size

params.description: The return type of the analysis, either "fft", or "waveform".
params.name: type

Compressor.description:
Tone.Compressor is a thin wrapper around the Web Audio 
        [DynamicsCompressorNode](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#the-dynamicscompressornode-interface).
        Compression reduces the volume of loud sounds or amplifies quiet sounds 
        by narrowing or "compressing" an audio signal's dynamic range. 
        Read more on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_range_compression).

params.description: The value above which the compression starts to be applied.
params.name: threshold

params.description: The gain reduction ratio.
params.name: ratio

examples: var comp = new Tone.Compressor(-30, 3);

CrossFade.description:
Tone.Crossfade provides equal power fading between two inputs. 
        More on crossfading technique [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fade_(audio_engineering)#Crossfading).

Envelope.description: Tone.Envelope is an [ADSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthesizer#ADSR_envelope) envelope generator. Tone.Envelope outputs a signal which can be connected to an AudioParam or Tone.Signal.

params.description:
The amount of time it takes for the envelope to go from 
                        0 to it's maximum value.
params.name: attack

params.description:
The period of time after the attack that it takes for the envelope
                      	to fall to the sustain value.
params.name: decay

params.description:
The percent of the maximum value that the envelope rests at until
                               	the release is triggered.
params.name: sustain

params.description: The amount of time after the release is triggered it takes to reach 0.
params.name: release

EQ3.description:
Tone.EQ3 is a three band EQ with control over low, mid, and high gain as
        well as the low and high crossover frequencies.

params.description: The gain applied to the lows.
params.name: lowLevel

params.description: The gain applied to the mid.
params.name: midLevel

params.description: The gain applied to the high.
params.name: highLevel

examples: var eq = new Tone.EQ3(-10, 3, -20);

FeedbackCombFilter.description:
Comb filters are basic building blocks for physical modeling. Read more
        about comb filters on [CCRMA's website](https://ccrma.stanford.edu/~jos/pasp/Feedback_Comb_Filters.html).

params.description: The delay time of the filter.
params.name: delayTime

params.description: The amount of feedback the filter has.
params.name: resonance

Filter.description:
Tone.Filter is a filter which allows for all of the same native methods
         as the [BiquadFilterNode](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#the-biquadfilternode-interface). 
         Tone.Filter has the added ability to set the filter rolloff at -12 
         (default), -24 and -48.

params.description: The cutoff frequency of the filter.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The type of filter.
params.name: type

params.description:
The drop in decibels per octave after the cutoff frequency.
                           3 choices: -12, -24, and -48
params.name: rolloff

examples: var filter = new Tone.Filter(200, "highpass");

Follower.description:
Tone.Follower is a  crude envelope follower which will follow 
         the amplitude of an incoming signal. 
         Take care with small (< 0.02) attack or decay values 
         as follower has some ripple which is exaggerated
         at these values. Read more about envelope followers (also known 
         as envelope detectors) on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Envelope_detector).

params.description: The rate at which the follower rises.
params.name: attack

params.description: The rate at which the folower falls.
params.name: release

examples: var follower = new Tone.Follower(0.2, 0.4);

FrequencyEnvelope.description:
Tone.FrequencyEnvelope is a Tone.ScaledEnvelope, but instead of `min` and `max`
        it's got a `baseFrequency` and `octaves` parameter.

params.description: the attack time in seconds
params.name: attack

params.description: the decay time in seconds
params.name: decay

params.description: a percentage (0-1) of the full amplitude
params.name: sustain

params.description: the release time in seconds
params.name: release

Gate.description:
Tone.Gate only passes a signal through when the incoming 
         signal exceeds a specified threshold. To do this, Gate uses 
         a Tone.Follower to follow the amplitude of the incoming signal. 
         A common implementation of this class is a [Noise Gate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise_gate).

params.description: The threshold above which the gate will open.
params.name: threshold

params.description: The follower's attack time
params.name: attack

params.description: The follower's release time
params.name: release

LFO.description:
LFO stands for low frequency oscillator. Tone.LFO produces an output signal 
         which can be attached to an AudioParam or Tone.Signal 
         in order to modulate that parameter with an oscillator. The LFO can 
         also be synced to the transport to start/stop and change when the tempo changes.

params.description:
The frequency of the oscillation. Typically, LFOs will be
                              in the frequency range of 0.1 to 10 hertz.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The minimum output value of the LFO.
params.name: min

params.description: The maximum value of the LFO.
params.name: max

examples:
var lfo = new Tone.LFO("4n", 400, 4000);
lfo.connect(filter.frequency);

Limiter.description:
Tone.Limiter will limit the loudness of an incoming signal. 
        It is composed of a Tone.Compressor with a fast attack 
        and release. Limiters are commonly used to safeguard against 
        signal clipping. Unlike a compressor, limiters do not provide 
        smooth gain reduction and almost completely prevent 
        additional gain above the threshold.

params.description: The theshold above which the limiting is applied.
params.name: threshold

examples: var limiter = new Tone.Limiter(-6);

LowpassCombFilter.description:
Tone.Lowpass is a lowpass feedback comb filter. It is similar to 
        Tone.FeedbackCombFilter, but includes a lowpass filter.

params.description: The delay time of the comb filter
params.name: delayTime

params.description: The resonance (feedback) of the comb filter
params.name: resonance

params.description:
The cutoff of the lowpass filter dampens the
                               signal as it is fedback.
params.name: dampening

Merge.description:
Tone.Merge brings two signals into the left and right 
         channels of a single stereo channel.

Meter.description:
Tone.Meter gets the [RMS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_mean_square) of an input signal with some averaging applied. It can also get the raw value of the signal or the value in dB. For signal processing, it's better to use Tone.Follower which will produce an audio-rate envelope follower instead of needing to poll the Meter to get the output.

Meter was inspired by [Chris Wilsons Volume Meter](https://github.com/cwilso/volume-meter/blob/master/volume-meter.js).

params.description: number of channels being metered
params.name: channels

params.description: amount of smoothing applied to the volume
params.name: smoothing

params.description: number in seconds that a "clip" should be remembered
params.name: clipMemory

MidSideCompressor.description:
Tone.MidSideCompressor applies two different compressors to the mid
        and side signal components. See Tone.MidSideSplit.

params.description:
The options that are passed to the mid and side
                         compressors.
params.name: options

MidSideMerge.description:
Mid/Side processing separates the the 'mid' signal (which comes out of both the left and the right channel) and the 'side' (which only comes out of the the side channels). MidSideMerge merges the mid and side signal after they've been seperated by Tone.MidSideSplit.

Left = (Mid+Side)/sqrt(2); // obtain left signal from mid and side
Right = (Mid-Side)/sqrt(2); // obtain right signal from mid and side

MidSideSplit.description:
Mid/Side processing separates the the 'mid' signal (which comes out of both the left and the right channel) and the 'side' (which only comes out of the the side channels).

Mid = (Left+Right)/sqrt(2); // obtain mid-signal from left and right
Side = (Left-Right)/sqrt(2); // obtain side-signal from left and righ

Mono.description:
Tone.Mono coerces the incoming mono or stereo signal into a mono signal
        where both left and right channels have the same value. This can be useful 
        for [stereo imaging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereo_imaging).

MultibandCompressor.description: A compressor with seperate controls over low/mid/high dynamics

params.description: The low/mid/high compressor settings.
params.name: options

MultibandSplit.description:
Split the incoming signal into three bands (low, mid, high)
        with two crossover frequency controls.

params.description: the low/mid crossover frequency
params.name: lowFrequency

params.description: the mid/high crossover frequency
params.name: highFrequency

Panner.description:
Tone.Panner is an equal power Left/Right Panner and does not
 support 3D. Panner uses the StereoPannerNode when available.

params.description: The initail panner value (defaults to 0.5 = center)
params.name: initialPan

examples:
//pan the input signal hard right. 
 var panner = new Tone.Panner(1);

PanVol.description: Tone.PanVol is a Tone.Panner and Tone.Volume in one.

params.description: the initial pan
params.name: pan

params.description: The output volume.
params.name: volume

examples:
//pan the incoming signal left and drop the volume
var panVol = new Tone.PanVol(0.25, -12);

ScaledEnvelope.description:
Tone.ScaledEnvelop is an envelope which can be scaled 
        to any range. It's useful for applying an envelope 
        to a frequency or any other non-NormalRange signal 
        parameter.

params.description: the attack time in seconds
params.name: attack

params.description: the decay time in seconds
params.name: decay

params.description: a percentage (0-1) of the full amplitude
params.name: sustain

params.description: the release time in seconds
params.name: release

Split.description: Tone.Split splits an incoming signal into left and right channels.
examples:
var split = new Tone.Split();
stereoSignal.connect(split);

Volume.description: Tone.Volume is a simple volume node, useful for creating a volume fader.

params.description: the initial volume
params.name: volume

examples:
var vol = new Tone.Volume(-12);
instrument.chain(vol, Tone.Master);

CtrlInterpolate.description:
Tone.CtrlInterpolate will interpolate between given values based
        on the "index" property. Passing in an array or object literal
        will interpolate each of the parameters. Note (i.e. "C3")
        and Time (i.e. "4n + 2") can be interpolated. All other values are
        assumed to be numbers.

params.description: The array of values to interpolate over
params.name: values

params.description: The initial interpolation index.
params.name: index

CtrlMarkov.description:
Tone.CtrlMarkov represents a Markov Chain where each call
        to Tone.CtrlMarkov.next will move to the next state. If the next
        state choice is an array, the next state is chosen randomly with
        even probability for all of the choices. For a weighted probability
        of the next choices, pass in an object with "state" and "probability" attributes. 
        The probabilities will be normalized and then chosen. If no next options
        are given for the current state, the state will stay there.

params.description:
An object with the state names as the keys
                        and the next state(s) as the values.
params.name: values

CtrlPattern.description:
Generate patterns from an array of values. Has a number of arpeggiation and randomized selection patterns.
  • "up" - cycles upward
  • "down" - cycles downward
  • "upDown" - up then and down
  • "downUp" - cycles down then and up
  • "alternateUp" - jump up two and down one
  • "alternateDown" - jump down two and up one
  • "random" - randomly select an index
  • "randomWalk" - randomly moves one index away from the current position
  • "randomOnce" - randomly select an index without repeating until all values have been chosen.

params.description: An array of options to choose from.
params.name: values

params.description: The name of the pattern.
params.name: type

params.description: The minimum return value.
params.name: min

params.description: The maximum return value.
params.name: max

Buffer.description:
Buffer loading and storage. Tone.Buffer is used internally by all classes that make requests for audio files such as Tone.Player, Tone.Sampler and Tone.Convolver.

Aside from load callbacks from individual buffers, Tone.Buffer provides static methods which keep track of the loading progress of all of the buffers. These methods are Tone.Buffer.onload, Tone.Buffer.onprogress, and Tone.Buffer.onerror.

params.description: The url to load, or the audio buffer to set.
params.name: url

params.description:
A callback which is invoked after the buffer is loaded. 
                           It's recommended to use Tone.Buffer.onload instead 
                           since it will give you a callback when ALL buffers are loaded.
params.name: onload

Clock.description:
A sample accurate clock which provides a callback at the given rate. 
         While the callback is not sample-accurate (it is still susceptible to
         loose JS timing), the time passed in as the argument to the callback
         is precise. For most applications, it is better to use Tone.Transport
         instead of the Clock by itself since you can synchronize multiple callbacks.

params.description: The callback to be invoked with the time of the audio event
params.name: callback

params.description: The rate of the callback
params.name: frequency

params.description: The delay applied to the incoming signal.
params.name: delayTime

params.description: The maximum delay time.
params.name: maxDelay

Emitter.description:
Tone.Emitter gives classes which extend it
        the ability to listen for and trigger events. 
        Inspiration and reference from Jerome Etienne's [MicroEvent](https://github.com/jeromeetienne/microevent.js).
        MIT (c) 2011 Jerome Etienne.

Gain.description:
A thin wrapper around the Native Web Audio GainNode.
        The GainNode is a basic building block of the Web Audio
        API and is useful for routing audio and adjusting gains.

params.description: The initial gain of the GainNode
params.name: gain

params.description: The units of the gain parameter.
params.name: units

IntervalTimeline.description:
Similar to Tone.Timeline, but all events represent
        intervals with both "time" and "duration" times. The 
        events are placed in a tree structure optimized
        for querying an intersection point with the timeline
        events. Internally uses an [Interval Tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_tree)
        to represent the data.

Master.description:
A single master output which is connected to the AudioDestinationNode (aka your speakers). It provides useful conveniences such as the ability to set the volume and mute the entire application. It also gives you the ability to apply master effects to your application.

Like Tone.Transport, A single Tone.Master is created on initialization and you do not need to explicitly construct one.

Note.description:
A timed note. Creating a note will register a callback 
         which will be invoked on the channel at the time with
         whatever value was specified.

params.description: the channel name of the note
params.name: channel

params.description: the time when the note will occur
params.name: time

params.description: the value of the note
params.name: value

Param.description:
Tone.Param wraps the native Web Audio's AudioParam to provide
        additional unit conversion functionality. It also
        serves as a base-class for classes which have a single,
        automatable parameter.

params.description: The parameter to wrap.
params.name: param

params.description: The units of the audio param.
params.name: units

params.description: If the param should be converted.
params.name: convert

Timeline.description:
A Timeline class for scheduling and maintaining state
        along a timeline. All events must have a "time" property. 
        Internally, events are stored in time order for fast 
        retrieval.

params.description: The number of previous events that are retained.
params.name: memory

TimelineState.description: A Timeline State. Provides the methods: setStateAtTime("state", time) and getStateAtTime(time).

params.description: The initial state of the TimelineState. Defaults to undefined
params.name: initial

Tone.description:
Tone is the base class of all other classes. It provides 
         a lot of methods and functionality to all classes that extend
         it.

params.description: the number of input nodes
params.name: inputs

params.description: the number of output nodes
params.name: outputs

Transport.description:
Transport for timing musical events. Supports tempo curves and time changes. Unlike browser-based timing (setInterval, requestAnimationFrame) Tone.Transport timing events pass in the exact time of the scheduled event in the argument of the callback function. Pass that time value to the object you're scheduling.

A single transport is created for you when the library is initialized.

The transport emits the events: "start", "stop", "pause", and "loop" which are called with the time of that event as the argument.

AutoFilter.description:
Tone.AutoFilter is a Tone.Filter with a Tone.LFO connected to the filter cutoff frequency.
        Setting the LFO rate and depth allows for control over the filter modulation rate 
        and depth.

params.description: The rate of the LFO.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The lower value of the LFOs oscillation
params.name: baseFrequency

params.description: The number of octaves above the baseFrequency
params.name: octaves

AutoPanner.description:
Tone.AutoPanner is a Tone.Panner with an LFO connected to the pan amount. 
        More on using autopanners [here](https://www.ableton.com/en/blog/autopan-chopper-effect-and-more-liveschool/).

params.description: Rate of left-right oscillation.
params.name: frequency

AutoWah.description:
Tone.AutoWah connects a Tone.Follower to a bandpass filter (Tone.Filter).
         The frequency of the filter is adjusted proportionally to the 
         incoming signal's amplitude. Inspiration from [Tuna.js](https://github.com/Dinahmoe/tuna).

params.description:
The frequency the filter is set 
                                           to at the low point of the wah
params.name: baseFrequency

params.description:
The number of octaves above the baseFrequency
                               the filter will sweep to when fully open
params.name: octaves

params.description:
The decibel threshold sensitivity for 
                                  the incoming signal. Normal range of -40 to 0.
params.name: sensitivity

BitCrusher.description:
Tone.Bitcrusher downsamples the incoming signal to a different bitdepth. 
        Lowering the bitdepth of the signal creates distortion. Read more about Bitcrushing
        on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcrusher).

params.description:
The number of bits to downsample the signal. Nominal range
                      of 1 to 8.
params.name: bits

Chebyshev.description:
Tone.ChebyShev is a Chebyshev waveshaper, an effect which is good 
        for making different types of distortion sounds.
        Note that odd orders sound very different from even ones, 
        and order = 1 is no change. 
        Read more at [music.columbia.edu](http://music.columbia.edu/cmc/musicandcomputers/chapter4/04_06.php).

params.description: The order of the chebyshev polynomial. Normal range between 1-100.
params.name: order

Chorus.description:
Tone.Chorus is a stereo chorus effect with feedback composed of 
        a left and right delay with a Tone.LFO applied to the delayTime of each channel. 
        Inspiration from [Tuna.js](https://github.com/Dinahmoe/tuna/blob/master/tuna.js).
        Read more on the chorus effect on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/jun04/articles/synthsecrets.htm).

params.description: The frequency of the LFO.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The delay of the chorus effect in ms.
params.name: delayTime

params.description: The depth of the chorus.
params.name: depth

Convolver.description:
Tone.Convolver is a wrapper around the Native Web Audio 
         [ConvolverNode](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#the-convolvernode-interface).
         Convolution is useful for reverb and filter emulation. Read more about convolution reverb on
         [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution_reverb).

params.description:
The URL of the impulse response or the Tone.Buffer
                                          contianing the impulse response.
params.name: url

Distortion.description:
Tone.Distortion is a simple distortion effect using Tone.WaveShaper.
        Algorithm from [a stackoverflow answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/22313408).

params.description: The amount of distortion (nominal range of 0-1)
params.name: distortion

Effect.description:
Tone.Effect is the base class for effects. Connect the effect between
	        the effectSend and effectReturn GainNodes, then control the amount of
	        effect which goes to the output using the wet control.

params.description: The starting wet value.
params.name: wet

FeedbackDelay.description:
Tone.FeedbackDelay is a DelayNode in which part of output
         signal is fed back into the delay.

params.description: The delay applied to the incoming signal.
params.name: delayTime

params.description:
The amount of the effected signal which 
                           is fed back through the delay.
params.name: feedback

FeedbackEffect.description:
Tone.FeedbackEffect provides a loop between an 
	        audio source and its own output. This is a base-class
	        for feedback effects.

params.description: The initial feedback value.
params.name: feedback

Freeverb.description:
Tone.Freeverb is a reverb based on [Freeverb](https://ccrma.stanford.edu/~jos/pasp/Freeverb.html).
        Read more on reverb on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/may00/articles/reverb.htm).

params.description: Correlated to the decay time.
params.name: roomSize

params.description:
The cutoff frequency of a lowpass filter as part 
                                of the reverb.
params.name: dampening

JCReverb.description:
Tone.JCReverb is a simple [Schroeder Reverberator](https://ccrma.stanford.edu/~jos/pasp/Schroeder_Reverberators.html)
        tuned by John Chowning in 1970.
        It is made up of three allpass filters and four Tone.FeedbackCombFilter.

params.description: Coorelates to the decay time.
params.name: roomSize

MidSideEffect.description:
Mid/Side processing separates the the 'mid' signal (which comes out of both the left and the right channel) and the 'side' (which only comes out of the the side channels) and effects them separately before being recombined. Applies a Mid/Side seperation and recombination. Algorithm found in [kvraudio forums](http://www.kvraudio.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=212587).

This is a base-class for Mid/Side Effects.

Phaser.description:
Tone.Phaser is a phaser effect. Phasers work by changing the phase
        of different frequency components of an incoming signal. Read more on 
        [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaser_(effect)). 
        Inspiration for this phaser comes from [Tuna.js](https://github.com/Dinahmoe/tuna/).

params.description: The speed of the phasing.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The octaves of the effect.
params.name: octaves

params.description: The base frequency of the filters.
params.name: baseFrequency

PingPongDelay.description:
Tone.PingPongDelay is a feedback delay effect where the echo is heard
         first in one channel and next in the opposite channel. In a stereo
         system these are the right and left channels.
         PingPongDelay in more simplified terms is two Tone.FeedbackDelays 
         with independent delay values. Each delay is routed to one channel
         (left or right), and the channel triggered second will always 
         trigger at the same interval after the first.

params.description: The delayTime between consecutive echos.
params.name: delayTime

params.description:
The amount of the effected signal which 
                                is fed back through the delay.
params.name: feedback

PitchShift.description:
Tone.PitchShift does near-realtime pitch shifting to the incoming signal. 
        The effect is achieved by speeding up or slowing down the delayTime
        of a DelayNode using a sawtooth wave. 
        Algorithm found in [this pdf](http://dsp-book.narod.ru/soundproc.pdf).
        Additional reference by [Miller Pucket](http://msp.ucsd.edu/techniques/v0.11/book-html/node115.html).

params.description: The interval to transpose the incoming signal by.
params.name: pitch

StereoEffect.description: Base class for Stereo effects. Provides effectSendL/R and effectReturnL/R.

StereoFeedbackEffect.description:
Base class for stereo feedback effects where the effectReturn
        is fed back into the same channel.

StereoWidener.description:
Applies a width factor to the mid/side seperation. 0 is all mid and 1 is all side. Algorithm found in [kvraudio forums](http://www.kvraudio.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=212587).

Mid *= 2*(1-width)
Side *= 2*width

params.description: The stereo width. A width of 0 is mono and 1 is stereo. 0.5 is no change.
params.name: width

StereoXFeedbackEffect.description:
Just like a stereo feedback effect, but the feedback is routed from left to right
        and right to left instead of on the same channel.

Tremolo.description:
Tone.Tremolo modulates the amplitude of an incoming signal using a Tone.LFO.
        The type, frequency, and depth of the LFO is controllable.

params.description: The rate of the effect.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The depth of the effect.
params.name: depth

Vibrato.description:
A Vibrato effect composed of a Tone.Delay and a Tone.LFO. The LFO
        modulates the delayTime of the delay, causing the pitch to rise
        and fall.

params.description: The frequency of the vibrato.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The amount the pitch is modulated.
params.name: depth

Event.description:
Tone.Event abstracts away Tone.Transport.schedule and provides a schedulable
         callback for a single or repeatable events along the timeline.

params.description: The callback to invoke at the time.
params.name: callback

params.description:
The value or values which should be passed to
                     the callback function on invocation.
params.name: value

Loop.description:
Tone.Loop creates a looped callback at the 
        specified interval. The callback can be 
        started, stopped and scheduled along
        the Transport's timeline.

params.description:
The callback to invoke with the
                            event.
params.name: callback

params.description: The events to arpeggiate over.
params.name: events

Part.description:
Tone.Part is a collection Tone.Events which can be
        started/stoped and looped as a single unit.

params.description: The callback to invoke on each event
params.name: callback

params.description: the array of events
params.name: events

Pattern.description:
Tone.Pattern arpeggiates between the given notes
        in a number of patterns. See Tone.CtrlPattern for
        a full list of patterns.

params.description:
The callback to invoke with the
                            event.
params.name: callback

params.description: The events to arpeggiate over.
params.name: events

Sequence.description:
A sequence is an alternate notation of a part. Instead
        of passing in an array of [time, event] pairs, pass
        in an array of events which will be spaced at the
        given subdivision. Sub-arrays will subdivide that beat
        by the number of items are in the array. 
        Sequence notation inspiration from [Tidal](http://yaxu.org/tidal/)

params.description: The callback to invoke with every note
params.name: callback

params.description: The sequence
params.name: events

params.description: The subdivision between which events are placed.
params.name: subdivision

AMSynth.description: AMSynth uses the output of one Tone.MonoSynth to modulate the amplitude of another Tone.MonoSynth. The harmonicity (the ratio between the two signals) affects the timbre of the output signal the most. Read more about Amplitude Modulation Synthesis on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/mar00/articles/synthsecrets.htm).

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                           see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var synth = new Tone.AMSynth().toMaster();
synth.triggerAttackRelease("C4", "4n");

DrumSynth.description: Tone.DrumSynth makes kick and tom sounds using a single oscillator with an amplitude envelope and frequency ramp. A Tone.Oscillator is routed through a Tone.AmplitudeEnvelope to the output. The drum quality of the sound comes from the frequency envelope applied during during Tone.DrumSynth.triggerAttack(note). The frequency envelope starts at note * .octaves and ramps to note over the duration of .pitchDecay.

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var synth = new Tone.DrumSynth().toMaster();
synth.triggerAttackRelease("C2", "8n");

DuoSynth.description: Tone.DuoSynth is a monophonic synth composed of two MonoSynths run in parallel with control over the frequency ratio between the two voices and vibrato effect.

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var duoSynth = new Tone.DuoSynth().toMaster();
duoSynth.triggerAttackRelease("C4", "2n");

FMSynth.description: FMSynth is composed of two Tone.MonoSynths where one Tone.MonoSynth modulates the frequency of a second Tone.MonoSynth. A lot of spectral content can be explored using the modulationIndex parameter. Read more about frequency modulation synthesis on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/apr00/articles/synthsecrets.htm).

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var fmSynth = new Tone.FMSynth().toMaster();
fmSynth.triggerAttackRelease("C5", "4n");

Monophonic.description:
This is an abstract base class for other monophonic instruments to 
         extend. IMPORTANT: It does not make any sound on its own and
         shouldn't be directly instantiated.

MonoSynth.description: Tone.MonoSynth is composed of one oscillator, one filter, and two envelopes. The amplitude of the Tone.Oscillator and the cutoff frequency of the Tone.Filter are controlled by Tone.Envelopes.

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

NoiseSynth.description: Tone.NoiseSynth is composed of a noise generator (Tone.Noise), one filter (Tone.Filter), and two envelopes (Tone.Envelop). One envelope controls the amplitude of the noise and the other is controls the cutoff frequency of the filter.

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var noiseSynth = new Tone.NoiseSynth().toMaster();
noiseSynth.triggerAttackRelease("8n");

PluckSynth.description:
Karplus-String string synthesis. Often out of tune. 
        Will change when the AudioWorkerNode is available across
        browsers.

params.description: see the defaults
params.name: options

examples:
var plucky = new Tone.PluckSynth().toMaster();
plucky.triggerAttack("C4");

PolySynth.description:
Tone.PolySynth handles voice creation and allocation for any
         instruments passed in as the second paramter. PolySynth is 
         not a synthesizer by itself, it merely manages voices of 
         one of the other types of synths, allowing any of the 
         monophonic synthesizers to be polyphonic.

params.description: The number of voices to create
params.name: polyphony

params.description:
The constructor of the voices
                                           uses Tone.MonoSynth by default.
params.name: voice

Sampler.description: A sampler instrument which plays an audio buffer through an amplitude envelope and a filter envelope. The sampler takes an Object in the constructor which maps a sample name to the URL of the sample. Nested Objects will be flattened and can be accessed using a dot notation (see the example).

params.description: the urls of the audio file
params.name: urls

params.description: the options object for the synth
params.name: options

SimpleAM.description: AMSynth uses the output of one Tone.SimpleSynth to modulate the amplitude of another Tone.SimpleSynth. The harmonicity (the ratio between the two signals) affects the timbre of the output signal the most. Read more about Amplitude Modulation Synthesis on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/mar00/articles/synthsecrets.htm).

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var synth = new Tone.SimpleAM().toMaster();
synth.triggerAttackRelease("C4", "8n");

SimpleFM.description: SimpleFM is composed of two Tone.SimpleSynths where one Tone.SimpleSynth modulates the frequency of a second Tone.SimpleSynth. A lot of spectral content can be explored using the Tone.FMSynth.modulationIndex parameter. Read more about frequency modulation synthesis on [SoundOnSound](http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/apr00/articles/synthsecrets.htm).

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var fmSynth = new Tone.SimpleFM().toMaster();
fmSynth.triggerAttackRelease("C4", "8n");

SimpleSynth.description: Tone.SimpleSynth is composed simply of a Tone.OmniOscillator routed through a Tone.AmplitudeEnvelope.

params.description:
the options available for the synth 
                         see defaults below
params.name: options

examples:
var synth = new Tone.SimpleSynth().toMaster();
synth.triggerAttackRelease("C4", "8n");

Abs.description: Return the absolute value of an incoming signal.

Add.description: Add a signal and a number or two signals. When no value is passed into the constructor, Tone.Add will sum input[0] and input[1]. If a value is passed into the constructor, the it will be added to the input.

params.description:
If no value is provided, Tone.Add will sum the first
                        and second inputs.
params.name: value

AND.description:
[AND](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_conjunction)
        returns 1 when all the inputs are equal to 1 and returns 0 otherwise.

params.description:
the number of inputs. NOTE: all inputs are
                                connected to the single AND input node
params.name: inputCount

AudioToGain.description:
AudioToGain converts an input in AudioRange [-1,1] to NormalRange [0,1]. 
        See Tone.GainToAudio.
examples: var a2g = new Tone.AudioToGain();

Clip.description: Clip the incoming signal so that the output is always between min and max.

params.description: the minimum value of the outgoing signal
params.name: min

params.description: the maximum value of the outgoing signal
params.name: max

Equal.description:
Output 1 if the signal is equal to the value, otherwise outputs 0. 
         Can accept two signals if connected to inputs 0 and 1.

params.description: The number to compare the incoming signal to
params.name: value

EqualPowerGain.description: Convert an incoming signal between 0, 1 to an equal power gain scale.
examples: var eqPowGain = new Tone.EqualPowerGain();

EqualZero.description:
EqualZero outputs 1 when the input is equal to 
         0 and outputs 0 otherwise.

Expr.description:
Evaluate an expression at audio rate.

Parsing code modified from https://code.google.com/p/tapdigit/ Copyright 2011 2012 Ariya Hidayat, New BSD License

params.description: the expression to generate
params.name: expr

examples:
//adds the signals from input[0] and input[1].
var expr = new Tone.Expr("$0 + $1");

GainToAudio.description:
Maps a NormalRange [0, 1] to an AudioRange [-1, 1]. 
        See also Tone.AudioToGain.
examples: var g2a = new Tone.GainToAudio();

GreaterThan.description:
Output 1 if the signal is greater than the value, otherwise outputs 0.
         can compare two signals or a signal and a number.

params.description: the value to compare to the incoming signal
params.name: value

GreaterThanZero.description: GreaterThanZero outputs 1 when the input is strictly greater than zero

IfThenElse.description:
IfThenElse has three inputs. When the first input (if) is true (i.e. === 1), 
        then it will pass the second input (then) through to the output, otherwise, 
        if it's not true (i.e. === 0) then it will pass the third input (else) 
        through to the output.

LessThan.description:
Output 1 if the signal is less than the value, otherwise outputs 0.
         Can compare two signals or a signal and a number.

params.description: The value to compare to the incoming signal. If no value is provided, it will compare input[0] and input[1]
params.name: value

Max.description:
Outputs the greater of two signals. If a number is provided in the constructor
	        it will use that instead of the signal.

params.description:
Max value if provided. if not provided, it will use the
                      signal value from input 1.
params.name: max

Min.description:
Outputs the lesser of two signals. If a number is given 
	        in the constructor, it will use a signal and a number.

params.description: The minimum to compare to the incoming signal
params.name: min

Modulo.description:
Signal-rate modulo operator. Only works in AudioRange [-1, 1] and for modulus
        values in the NormalRange.

params.description: The modulus to apply.
params.name: modulus

Multiply.description:
Multiply two incoming signals. Or, if a number is given in the constructor, 
         multiplies the incoming signal by that value.

params.description:
Constant value to multiple. If no value is provided,
                        it will return the product of the first and second inputs
params.name: value

Negate.description: Negate the incoming signal. i.e. an input signal of 10 will output -10

Normalize.description: Normalize takes an input min and max and maps it linearly to NormalRange [0,1]

params.description: the min input value
params.name: inputMin

params.description: the max input value
params.name: inputMax

NOT.description:
Just an alias for Tone.EqualZero, but has the same effect as a NOT operator. 
         Outputs 1 when input equals 0.

OR.description:
[OR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR_gate)
        the inputs together. True if at least one of the inputs is true.

params.description: the input count
params.name: inputCount

Pow.description:
Pow applies an exponent to the incoming signal. The incoming signal
        must be AudioRange.

params.description: The exponent to apply to the incoming signal, must be at least 2.
params.name: exp

Route.description: Route a single input to the specified output.

params.description: the number of inputs the switch accepts
params.name: outputCount

Scale.description:
Performs a linear scaling on an input signal.
         Scales a NormalRange input to between
         outputMin and outputMax.

params.description: The output value when the input is 0.
params.name: outputMin

params.description: The output value when the input is 1.
params.name: outputMax

ScaleExp.description:
Performs an exponential scaling on an input signal.
         Scales a NormalRange value [0,1] exponentially
         to the output range of outputMin to outputMax.

params.description: The output value when the input is 0.
params.name: outputMin

params.description: The output value when the input is 1.
params.name: outputMax

params.description: The exponent which scales the incoming signal.
params.name: exponent

examples:
var scaleExp = new Tone.ScaleExp(0, 100, 2);
var signal = new Tone.Signal(0.5).connect(scaleExp);

Select.description:
Select between any number of inputs, sending the one 
        selected by the gate signal to the output

params.description: the number of inputs the switch accepts
params.name: sourceCount

Signal.description:
A signal is an audio-rate value. Tone.Signal is a core component of the library.
         Unlike a number, Signals can be scheduled with sample-level accuracy. Tone.Signal
         has all of the methods available to native Web Audio 
         [AudioParam](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#the-audioparam-interface)
         as well as additional conveniences. Read more about working with signals 
         [here](https://github.com/Tonejs/Tone.js/wiki/Signals).

params.description:
Initial value of the signal. If an AudioParam
                                    is passed in, that parameter will be wrapped
                                    and controlled by the Signal.
params.name: value

params.description: unit The units the signal is in.
params.name: units

examples: var signal = new Tone.Signal(10);

SignalBase.description: Base class for all Signals. Used Internally.

Subtract.description: Subtract the signal connected to input[1] from the signal connected to input[0]. If an argument is provided in the constructor, the signals .value will be subtracted from the incoming signal.

params.description:
The value to subtract from the incoming signal. If the value
                        is omitted, it will subtract the second signal from the first.
params.name: value

Switch.description:
When the gate is set to 0, the input signal does not pass through to the output. 
         If the gate is set to 1, the input signal passes through.
         the gate is initially closed.

params.description: If the gate is initially open or closed.
params.name: open

TimelineSignal.description:
A signal which adds the method getValueAtTime. 
        Code and inspiration from https://github.com/jsantell/web-audio-automation-timeline

params.description: The initial value of the signal
params.name: value

params.description: The conversion units of the signal.
params.name: units

WaveShaper.description:
Wraps the native Web Audio API 
        [WaveShaperNode](http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/#the-waveshapernode-interface).

params.description:
The function used to define the values. 
                                   The mapping function should take two arguments: 
                                   the first is the value at the current position 
                                   and the second is the array position. 
                                   If the argument is an array, that array will be
                                   set as the wave shaping function. The input
                                   signal is an AudioRange [-1, 1] value and the output
                                   signal can take on any numerical values.
params.name: mapping

params.description: The length of the WaveShaperNode buffer.
params.name: bufferLen

examples:
//a waveshaper can also be constructed with an array of values
var invert = new Tone.WaveShaper([1, -1]);

ExternalInput.description:
Tone.ExternalInput is a WebRTC Audio Input. Check 
         [Media Stream API Support](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaStream_API)
         to see which browsers are supported. As of
         writing this, Chrome, Firefox, and Opera 
         support Media Stream. Chrome allows enumeration 
         of the sources, and access to device name over a 
         secure (HTTPS) connection. See [https://simpl.info](https://simpl.info/getusermedia/sources/index.html) 
         vs [http://simple.info](https://simpl.info/getusermedia/sources/index.html) 
         on a Chrome browser for the difference.

params.description: If multiple inputs are present, select the input number. Chrome only.
params.name: inputNum

Microphone.description: Opens up the default source (typically the microphone).

Noise.description:
Tone.Noise is a noise generator. It uses looped noise buffers to save on performance.
         Tone.Noise supports the noise types: "pink", "white", and "brown". Read more about
         colors of noise on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colors_of_noise).

params.description: the noise type (white|pink|brown)
params.name: type

OmniOscillator.description:
Tone.OmniOscillator aggregates Tone.Oscillator, Tone.PulseOscillator,
        and Tone.PWMOscillator into one class, allowing it to have the 
        types: sine, square, triangle, sawtooth, pulse or pwm. Additionally,
        OmniOscillator is capable of setting the first x number of partials 
        of the oscillator. For example: "sine4" would set be the first 4 
        partials of the sine wave and "triangle8" would set the first 
        8 partials of the triangle wave.

params.description: The initial frequency of the oscillator.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The type of the oscillator.
params.name: type

examples: var omniOsc = new Tone.OmniOscillator("C#4", "pwm");

Oscillator.description:
Tone.Oscillator supports a number of features including
        phase rotation, multiple oscillator types (see Tone.Oscillator.type), 
        and Transport syncing (see Tone.Oscillator.syncFrequency).

params.description: Starting frequency
params.name: frequency

params.description: The oscillator type. Read more about type below.
params.name: type

examples:
//make and start a 440hz sine tone
var osc = new Tone.Oscillator(440, "sine").toMaster().start();

Player.description: Tone.Player is an audio file player with start, loop, and stop functions.

params.description:
Either the AudioBuffer or the url from
                                 which to load the AudioBuffer
params.name: url

params.description:
The function to invoke when the buffer is loaded. 
                           Recommended to use Tone.Buffer.onload instead.
params.name: onload

PulseOscillator.description:
Tone.PulseOscillator is a pulse oscillator with control over pulse width,
        also known as the duty cycle. At 50% duty cycle (width = 0.5) the wave is 
        a square and only odd-numbered harmonics are present. At all other widths 
        even-numbered harmonics are present. Read more 
        [here](https://wigglewave.wordpress.com/2014/08/16/pulse-waveforms-and-harmonics/).

params.description: The frequency of the oscillator
params.name: frequency

params.description: The width of the pulse
params.name: width

examples: var pulse = new Tone.PulseOscillator("E5", 0.4).toMaster().start();

PWMOscillator.description:
Tone.PWMOscillator modulates the width of a Tone.PulseOscillator 
        at the modulationFrequency. This has the effect of continuously
        changing the timbre of the oscillator by altering the harmonics 
        generated.

params.description: The starting frequency of the oscillator.
params.name: frequency

params.description: The modulation frequency of the width of the pulse.
params.name: modulationFrequency

examples: var pwm = new Tone.PWMOscillator("Ab3", 0.3).toMaster().start();

Source.description:
Base class for sources. Sources have start/stop methods
         and the ability to be synced to the 
         start/stop of Tone.Transport.
